message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a soap bubble appearance within the distal femur, which is indicative of osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma appears as a well-defined cartilaginous mass, aneurysmal bone cyst would show a bubbly, cystic appearance, and Ewing sarcoma is usually seen in children and is characterized by an onion skin appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a soap-bubble appearance, which is a characteristic feature of Osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma is usually located in the pelvis or spine, while aneurysmal bone cyst and Ewing sarcoma typically manifest with more aggressive features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows an osteolytic lesion with a well-defined border, which suggests the most likely diagnosis is Osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma would have a different appearance on x-ray, and Aneurysmal bone cyst typically presents with fluid-fluid levels on MRI, which is not seen here. Ewing sarcoma can present with similar symptoms, but it is more common in children and young adults, and it usually has a permeative appearance on x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a radiolucent lesion with sclerotic borders, which is characteristic of an osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma and aneurysmal bone cyst have different radiographic features, and Ewing sarcoma typically presents in younger patients and has a more aggressive course.

We refer to the x-ray image provided. Among the options, only osteoclastoma presents with a "soap-bubble" appearance on the x-ray, which is shown in this case. It is also the most common primary bone tumor in the knee region for this age group. Chondrosarcoma, aneurysmal bone cyst, and Ewing sarcoma typically present with different radiographic features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion in the distal femur with a sclerotic rim and a "soap bubble" appearance, which is characteristic of an osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma tends to be more central, aneurysmal bone cysts can have fluid-fluid levels, and Ewing sarcoma typically presents with a permeative pattern of bone destruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. From the x-ray, we can see an osteolytic lesion, which is commonly seen in osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma and aneurysmal bone cyst are typically seen in a younger age group, and Ewing sarcoma is typically seen in a different location, such as the pelvis or ribs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a well-defined, eccentric, lytic lesion with a thin rim of sclerosis, which is typically seen in Osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma usually presents as a large, expansile lesion with calcifications. An aneurysmal bone cyst is a blood-filled cystic lesion. Ewing sarcoma presents as a permeative lesion with aggressive periosteal reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a well-defined, expansile, radiolucent lesion with scattered areas of mineralization, which is characteristic of an osteoclastoma. Chondrosarcoma would have a more lobulated appearance, aneurysmal bone cyst would have a more “soap bubble” appearance, and Ewing sarcoma would have cortical destruction and periosteal reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows a lesion with destruction and erosion of the bone, indicating Osteoclastoma, also known as giant cell tumor of bone. Chondrosarcoma is a slow-growing malignant tumor that does not typically present with rapid pain and swelling. Aneurysmal bone cyst and Ewing sarcoma may present with pain and swelling, but the x-ray does not show the characteristic appearance of these conditions.
